{{Coord|25|02|37|N|121|33|45|E|display=title}} {{Infobox building |name = Songshan Cultural and Creative Park |native_name = 松山文創園區 |image = |opening = |location = [[Xinyi District|Xinyi]], [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] |building_type = |start_date = |completion_date = 1937 (as Matsuyama Tobacco Plant){{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitravel.net/frontsite/en/sceneryEnListAction.do?method=doFindByPk&menuId=1030501&scenerySerNo=2012062000000013 |title=:::Historic Sites - Songshan Cultural and Creative Park ::: TaipeiTravel Net - Department of Information and Tourism, Taipei City Government::: |publisher=Taipeitravel.net |date=2013-10-24 |accessdate=2014-02-10}}
2011 (as Songshan Cultural and Creative Park){{cite web|url=http://www.taiwanease.com/listing/3373/ |title=Taiwanease • Songshan Cultural and Creative Park |publisher=Taiwanease.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-10}} |cost = |roof = |top_floor = |architectural = |observatory = |floor_count = |floor_area = 6.6 hectares |elevator_count = |architect = |structural_engineer = |main_contractor = |management = |owner = |website = {{URL|http://www.songshanculturalpark.org/|www.songshanculturalpark.org}} |references = }} The '''Songshan Cultural and Creative Park''' ('''SSCC'''; {{zh|c=松山文創園區|p=Sōngshān Wénchuàng Yuánqū}}) is a multifunctional [[park]] in [[Xinyi District]], [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]]. ==History== The park was initially constructed in 1937 as a [[tobacco]] factory under the name {{nihongo|'''Matsuyama Tobacco Plant of the Monopoly Bureau of the Taiwan Governor's Office'''|臺灣總督府專賣局松山菸草工場}} under the [[Taiwan under Japanese rule|Japanese government]]. After [[Retrocession Day|Japan ceded Taiwan]] in 1945, the Taiwan Provincial Monopoly Bureau took over the factory and renamed it as the '''Songshan Tobacco Plant of the Taiwan Provincial Monopoly Bureau'''. In 1947, the plant was renamed again as '''Songshan Tobacco Plant of the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Bureau'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeiartplus.org/08.html |title=Taipei Art |publisher=Taipeiartplus.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-10}} The factory ceased to produce cigarettes in 1998 for concern over urban planning, tobacco and liquor marketing regulatory changes and the decline in tobacco demand. In 2001, the [[Taipei City Government]] designed the defunct tobacco factory as Taipei's 99th historic site and converted it into a park comprising city-designated historic sites, historical structures and architectural highlights. Together with [[Taipei Dome]], the site is known as '''Taipei Cultural and Sporting Complex'''. For more efficient reuse of space, in 2011 the former factory was turned into a creative park by its current name to provide venues for diverse cultural and creative exhibitions and performances. ==Purposes== The park has the following aims:{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} * Establish public platform and develop the cultural and creative industry; * Cultivate culture and creativity and cross industry exchanges; * Develop innovative experiments and set trends; * Provide cultural and arts education and encourage public involvement; * Spotlight the cultural and creative industry and put Taiwan on the map. ==Features== [[File:松山菸廠05.jpg|thumb|Warehouses (No. 1-5)]] [[File:Taiwan Design Museum 20130706.jpg|thumb|[[Taiwan Design Museum]]]] [[File:松山菸廠06.JPG|thumb|Tobacco Factory (North, South, East)]] [[File:Songshan Cultural and Creative Park.JPG|thumb|Baroque Garden]] [[File:松山菸廠04.jpg|thumb|TMSK Restaurant]] [[File:松山菸廠01.JPG|thumb|Boiler Room]] [[File:松山菸廠02.JPG|thumb|Nursery Room]] [[File:松山菸廠03.JPG|thumb|Ecology Pond]] The park consists of:{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} ===Warehouses=== There are five warehouses, from number 1 until 5. The workers manufactured cigarettes on the second floor of the plant. After packaging the rolled cigarettes, the boxes were sent directly to warehouse no. 2 using conveyor channel, through the turntable, directed to the platforms for delivery, hence reducing manual labor. ===Inspection Room=== The inspection room served as the place for employees and officers had to pass through when reporting for or getting off work. It had stationed guards on duty. ===Office Building=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Taiwan Design=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Taiwan Design Museum=== The [[Taiwan Design Museum]] building used to house the office for supervisors and officers of the tobacco plant. The office had also conference rooms and rest areas for guests. Ordinary plant employees were not allowed to access the building. ===Innovative Design Lab=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Tobacco Factory=== The tobacco factory consists of three segments, which are North, South and East. The building has characteristics of long open hallways with no dividing walls. The first floor mainly comprises columns to support the weight of the machines on the second floor. ===Baroque Garden=== Enclosed by the tobacco factory three sections, the garden has a fountain that is surrounded by sculptures of naked women emerging from their baths. ===TMSK Restaurant=== The building which now houses the TMSK restaurant used to be the machine repair plant building. The machine repair plant was exclusively responsible for the reparation and maintenance of the tobacco producing machines. ===Boiler Room=== The boiler room acted as the power source for the tobacco plant. [[Coal]] was burnt here to provide power for the plant. The chimneys were used to expel the smoke generated. ===Nursery Room=== There used to be 1,200 employees working at the plant at the same time. The tobacco plant had an industrial village concept, in which it included facilities such as cafeterias, shower facilities, dormitories, hospital, food mall, dining rooms, entertainment rooms and nursery. The nursery room served as a place for the infants of the employees to rest and play. ===Ecology Pond=== For fire extinguishing, ventilation and hydrosphere purposes, a large lotus pond was installed. It is now revamped as an ecology pond where children can enjoy the sounds of frogs and insects and experience the beauty of ecology. ===West 201 Conference Room=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===SSCC Management Center=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Taiwan Design Center=== The '''Taiwan Design Center''' ('''TDC'''; {{zh|t=台灣創意設計中心}}) is a national design center established to promote the development of the cultural and creative industry in which it acts as the integrated platform to promote creative design. It was established in 2003 and become officially operational in 2004. The main mission of TDC is to upgrade original creativity of Taiwanese designers, promote international design exchange, upgrade market competitiveness of Taiwanese industries, help enterprises build up their own brand, raise value-added of such industries and tell the world that the era of ''Designed in Taiwan'' has come.{{cite web|url=http://www.tdc.org.tw/en_about01.htm |title=Taiwan Design Center-About |publisher=Tdc.org.tw |date= |accessdate=2014-02-10}} ===TDC Information Center=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Design Library=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Creative Forum=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} ===Multi-Showcase Hall=== {{empty section|date=February 2014}} [[File:Multi-Showcase Hall, Songshan Cultural and Creative Park 20151031.jpg|thumb|Multi-Showcase Hall]] ==Transportation== The park is accessible within walking distance northeast from [[Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall Station (Taipei Metro)|Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall Station]] or North West from [[Taipei City Hall Station]] of the [[Taipei Metro]].{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} ==See also== * [[List of tourist attractions in Taiwan]] * [[List of parks in Taiwan]] * [[Taiwan Design Museum]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Former Songshan Tobacco Factory}} * [http://www.tdc.org.tw/en_index.htm Taiwan Design Center website] * [http://www.tdm.org.tw/ Taiwan Design Museum website] {{zh icon}} [[Category:1937 establishments in Taiwan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Taipei]] [[Category:Cultural centers in Taiwan]] [[Category:Tobacco in Taiwan]] [[Category:Industrial buildings completed in 1937]] [[Category:Museum districts]] [[Category:History of tobacco]] [[Category:Tobacco buildings]]

The '''Symphony No. 2''' by [[England|English]] [[composer]] [[William Walton]] was commissioned by the [[Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Society]] to celebrate the city's 750th anniversary in 1957. The [[Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra]] conducted by [[John Pritchard (conductor)|John Pritchard]] gave the first performance on 2 September 1960 at the [[Edinburgh International Festival|Edinburgh Festival]]. [[George Szell]] gave the Continental Premiere with the [[Concertgebouw Orchestra]] in Amsterdam on 19 November 1960. Szell also conducted the US Premiere of the work on 29 December 1960 with the Cleveland Orchestra in that city and a few months later they made its first recording. [[Leopold Stokowski]] gave the work another early Continental performance in Vienna in May 1961 while on tour with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]].
The work is in three movements.
# [[Tempo#Italian tempo markings|Allegro]] molto # [[Tempo|Lento]] assai # [[Passacaglia]]: Theme, Variations, Fugato, and Coda-Scherzando
It is scored for a large symphony orchestra comprising 3 [[flute]]s (3rd doubling [[piccolo]]), 3 [[oboe]]s (3rd doubling [[cor anglais]]), 3 [[clarinet]]s (2nd doubling [[clarinet in E-flat]], 3rd doubling [[bass clarinet]]), 3 [[bassoon]]s (3rd doubling [[contrabassoon]]), 4 [[French horn|horns]], 3 [[trumpet]]s, 3 [[trombone]]s, [[tuba]], [[timpani]], military drum, snare drum, crash cymbals, suspended cymbal, bass drum, glockenspiel, vibraphone, xylophone, tambourine, bell, [[piano]], [[celesta]], 2 [[harp]]s and [[String instrument|strings]].
The symphony was the subject of harsh press criticism on account of its seemingly conservative style at a time when the European avant-garde style was in its ascendance. With time, however, it has been recognised<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/william-walton-the-enfant-terrible-of-oldham-655757.html</ref>{{Failed verification|date=September 2017}}<!--As of 15 Sept. 2017, 17:05 BST, this links to a story headlined “Police admit they have no suspects after ‘home-made time bomb’ explodes inside London Tube train”. If this is really a review of Walton's Second Symphony, it is a harsh account, indeed.--> as a mature, subtle and superbly crafted work with many refinements of [[orchestration]], a characteristic of this composer.<ref>Kennedy, Michael (1989). ''Portrait of Walton''. Oxford University Press. pp 211–214</ref> The finale is notable for its use of a [[twelve-tone]] note-row,{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} a device used in [[twelve-tone technique]].
==References== <references />
==Further reading== *Adams, Byron. 2001. "Walton, Sir William (Turner)". ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (musicologist)|John Tyrrell]]. London: Macmillan Publishers. * [[Peter Heyworth|Heyworth, Peter]]. 1960. "Walton's New Symphony". ''The Observer'' (4 September): 24. * [Howe, Frank Stewart]. 1960a. "Walton's Second Symphony: Memorable First Performance". ''The Times'', issue 54867 (Saturday, 3 September): 9. * [Howe, Frank Stewart]. 1960b. "Modern Confusion in Styles and Values". ''The Times'', issue 54872 (Friday, 9 September): 4. * Lloyd-Jones, David. 1961. "Walton: Symphony No. 2". ''The Musical Times'' 102, No. 1417 (March): 170–71. * Matthew-Walker, Robert. 2002. "Aspects of Walton's Second Symphony". ''Tempo'', New Series, No. 221 (July): 29–33. * Wright, David C. F. 1990. [Letter to the editor]. ''Tempo'', New Series, No. 172 (March): 51.
{{William Walton}}
[[Category:Compositions by William Walton|Symphony 2]] [[Category:20th-century symphonies|Walton, William 2]] [[Category:1960 compositions]] [[Category:Music commissioned by the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Feminism and the arts]]; added [[Category:Feminist art organizations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | formation = May 24, 1983 | extinction = 1986 | type = Affinity group/ Activist Art group | status =Non-profit | purpose = Protest, performance activism, prankster art | affiliations = Livermore Action Group | volunteers = Ten founding members; nine additional volunteers | name = The Nuclear Beauty Parlor | founding_location = San Francisco, California, USA }}'''The Nuclear Beauty Parlor''' was a group of women artists active in protest and performance art of the [[nuclear freeze]] movement from 1983-1986 in San Francisco, California.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tompkins|first=J.H.|title=At the Midnight Hour: The Nuclear Beauty Parlor makes paying your taxes an unforgettable experience|newspaper=[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]|date=April 1986|quote=The Nuclear Beauty Parlor is friends, it is a theatre troupe and it is appalled citizens. The humor the Nuclear Beauty Parlor uses as an educational tool is a distinctive and compelling feature.}}</ref> Their name is synonymous with a music project they originated, the 45-RPM 7" single, ''The Nuclear Beauty Parlor''.<ref>{{cite web|author=RADAR Music|title=Radiation-related Music Page: The Nuclear Beauty Parlor|url=http://www.doseinfo-radar.com/Music.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kusf-archives.com/2012_08_08_archive.html | title = DJ Stevil | last = Radio Archives | first = KUSF in Exile | work = Re Styles and the Final Rinse "The Nuclear Beauty Parlor" 7-in | accessdate = August 7, 2012 }}</ref> Two members of the Nuclear Beauty Parlor wrote the lyrics to the song<ref>{{cite journal | date = 1984 | title = The Nuclear Beauty Parlor | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sfIbAQAAMAAJ&q=%22The+Nuclear+Beauty+Parlor%22&dq=%22The+Nuclear+Beauty+Parlor%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2X15U5ywMo2eqAaW1oDIDw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA | publisher = Matilda Publications | volume = 13 | issue = 1-6 | page = 27 | quote = This tongue-in-chic chorus comes from the Nuclear Beauty Parlor - San Francisco artists active in the disarmament movement. Their record, done in the style of the 1960's "girl groups," was written by beauticians Vicki Krohn and Denise Slattery, and performed by rock heavy Re Styles, formerly of the Tubes, on lead vocal. | magazine = [[Ms. Magazine]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=London|first=Hank|title=Re Styles and the Final Rinse, The Nuclear Beauty Parlor|newspaper=Artist Magazine|date=March 1984}}</ref> which debuted in the women’s jail following the 1983 blockade of [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]], one of the largest [[anti-nuclear protests in the United States]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Patricia|first=Porter|title=Blockader Explains New Activism|newspaper=[[Daily Cal]]|publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley]]|date=July 1, 1983}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Hauser|first=Luke|title=Direct Action|date=June 21, 2003|publisher=Groundwork|isbn=0974019402|pages=68–334|url=http://directaction.org/book/excerpts.html}}</ref> The group staged numerous performances to attract media attention for the cause of nuclear disarmament.<ref>{{cite news|title=There was a hot time in the tax line last night|newspaper=[[San Francisco Examiner]]|date=April 16, 1985}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pele|first=deLappe|title=The Nuclear Beauty Parlor, An Enlightening Experience|newspaper=People's World|date=January 7, 1984}}</ref> The record, conceived as an art prank,<ref>{{cite book|last=McCleod|first=Kembrew|title=Pranksters: Making Mischief in the Modern World|date=April 1, 2014|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=081479629X|quote=“If reduced to a mathematical formula, the art of pranking can be expressed as Performance Art + Satire x Media = Prank. Put simply, pranks are playful critiques performed within the public sphere and amplified by media.”}}</ref> is archived in the Peace Library at [[Swarthmore College]].<ref name="The Nuclear Beauty Parlor (Side A); Re Styles and the Final Rinse (Side A); Awake (Side B)">{{cite web|last1=Peace Collection|first1=Swarthmore College|title=Mary Jo and Walter Uphoff Collected Papers|url=http://www.swarthmore.edu/Library/peace/|format=Phonodisc}}</ref> The group is noted for adding humor and [[post-punk]] style to a dedicated protest movement.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schutzbank|first=Carol|title=The Nuclear Beauty Parlor|newspaper=Alternative Rhythms|date=October 1985}}</ref>
== History == On May 24, 1983, ten women formed an [[affinity group]] to prepare for the mass arrests planned for the International Day of Nuclear Disarmament protest of June 20, 1983.<ref>{{cite web|title=1,400 Anti-Nuclear Protesters Arrested|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB35CC6CE191FBE&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|publisher=Miami Herald}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Direct Action Web Feature International Day 1983|url=http://www.reclaimingquarterly.org/web/handbook/DA-Handbk-IntlDay83-lo.pdf}}</ref> They were trained in [[civil disobedience]] by Livermore Action Group.<ref>{{cite book|last=Klehr|first=Harvey|title=Far Left of Center|date=January 1, 1988|publisher=Transaction Publishers|isbn=0-88738-217-7|page=150|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8YSmiFins9sC&pg=PA150&lpg=PA150&dq=%22june+20,+1983%22+protest+anti-nuclear#v=onepage&q=%22june%2020%2C%201983%22%20protest%20anti-nuclear&f=false}}</ref> The female membership grew over the next 3 years, as they evolved into a [[performance art]] and activist art group.<ref>{{cite web|last=Boredom|first=Terminal|title=Field Guide to SF Art-Punk 1977-82ish|url=http://www.terminal-boredom.com/sfartguide.html}}</ref> Founding member Vicki Krohn Amorose <ref>{{cite web|last=Krohn Amorose|first=Vicki|title=Author PagesBiography|url=https://www.amazon.com/author/vickikrohnamorose|work=Art-Write: The Writing Guide for Visual Artists|publisher=Luminare Press}}</ref> originally coined the name ''Nuclear Beauty Parlor'' and she, along with founding member Denise Slattery, wrote the lyrics to the ''Nuclear Beauty Parlor'' song. The group was not a band; they enacted political satire in the tradition of [[guerrilla theatre]] and performance activism.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.feministactivism101.com/2014/03/performance-activism-and-guerilla-theatre.html | title = Performance Activism and Guerrilla Theatre | quote = Performance protest has been utilized in direct action by many different groups and movements because it is adaptable, non-threatening and effective. | last1 = McFarland | first1 = Ashley }}</ref>
== Activities == On June 20, 1983, the group participated in the blockade of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories. More than 1000 demonstrators were arrested, including three members of the Nuclear Beauty Parlor, and jailed for 11 days in tents on the grounds of the Alameda County Jail. The group gained their first media attention with a [[The San Francisco Examiner|San Francisco Examiner]] headline: ''Nuclear Beauty Parlor a Hit in Jail''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hernandez|first=Peggy|title=Nuclear Beauty Parlor a Hit in Jail|newspaper=San Francisco Examiner|date=June 23, 1983}}</ref> [[File:Cover art for side 1 Nuclear Beauty Parlor record.jpg|thumb|American activist group Nuclear Beauty Parlor's record cover]] During November and December,1983, the Nuclear Beauty Parlor acquired non-profit status, under the title Bay Area Energy Action. [[Bill Graham (promoter)]], San Francisco music impresario, funded production of the ''Nuclear Beauty Parlor'' 45-RPM 7" single. The lyrics were set to music and the record was produced by the group's friend and ally, Stacy Baird. Side A, ''The Nuclear Beauty Parlor'', was performed by Re Styles and other members of [[The Tubes]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Meltdown|first=Digital|title=The Nuclear Beauty Parlor/Awake split 7" (1983-320Kpbs)|url=http://digitalmeltd0wn.blogspot.com/2011/06/nuclear-beauty-parlorawake-split-7.html}}</ref> Side B, ''Awake'', was recorded at OTR Studios under the direction of [[Cookie Marenco]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Marenco|first=Cookie|title=Discography|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/590314-Cookie-Marenco|work=Awake}}</ref> The ''Nuclear Beauty Parlor'' 45-RPM single was released and a press conference held on Dec 15,1983.<ref>{{cite news|last=Richardson|first=Derek|title=Microgrooves|newspaper=San Francisco Bay Guardian|date=March 21, 1984}}</ref>
Between January and April, 1984, the group solidified its identity as a performance art group with the goal of gaining media attention for the nuclear freeze movement. The record gained airplay and press.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stefanac|first=Suzanne|title=Sing along with the Nuclear Beauty Parlor|newspaper=BAM Magazine|date=April 6, 1984}}</ref> On April 16, 1984, the group performs the first in a series of "Tax Day actions" at Rincon Annex Post Office in [[Rincon Center]]. Playing to the audience of taxpayers lined up in cars to meet the midnight tax-filing deadline, the Nuclear Beauty Parlor interacted as costumed waitresses, served weapon-themed food, and encourage people to: "Have one, you paid for it!" They attracted attention from TV and newspaper reporters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Many Ask for More Time on Taxes|newspaper=[[San Francisco Examiner]]|date=April 17, 1984}}</ref>
The [[Democratic National Convention]] was held in San Francisco on July 14 and 15, 1984. In conjunction with "A Vision of America at Peace", the Nuclear Beauty Parlor performed an original play with songs, titled "The First Lady Debate".<ref>{{cite news|last=Hoelterhoff|first=Manuela|title=Of Parades and Pinheads|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=July 18, 1984|quote=I bump into a group of young women wearing pink smocks that read "Nuclear Beauty Parlor." They are members of a guerrilla-theatre group that is about to put on a performance guaranteed, says one member, to make you curl up and die.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Perry|first=James M|title=Convention Site is Unconventional|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 12, 1984}}</ref> The group recorded "The First Lady Debate" and distributed tapes to radio stations nationwide.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hornbeak|first=Kathy|title=The Nuclear Beauty Parlor First Lady Debates|url=http://vimeo.com/38329242}}</ref>
On the eve of the Nov 6, 1984, presidential election, the group pasted thousands of anti-[[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]] posters in downtown San Francisco, designed by artist [[Paul Mavrides]], who also designed the record jacket.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mavrides|first=Paul|title=Published Work|url=http://artie.com/cm/art/artists/paulmavrides/resume.htm|work=The Nuclear Beauty Parlor, record jacket design and illustration}}</ref> Although the posters were quickly removed after Ronald Reagan’s victory, photographer C. Baldwin captured the morning-after image and created a postcard.
A December 1984 ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'' [[Ms. (magazine)|Magazine]] article on the group helped to boost record sales.<ref>{{cite journal|last=T|title=The Ms.Gazette News From All Over|journal=[[Ms. Magazine]]|date=December 1984|volume=XIII|issue=6|page=25}}</ref>
In their second Tax Day performance at Rincon Annex Post Office on April 15, 1985, The Nuclear Beauty Parlor dressed as couture nuclear weapons with price tags, and interacted with last-minute taxpayers, resulting in local TV and press coverage.<ref>{{cite news|last=Huges|first=Beth|title=Party Time for Tax Protesters on Final Day|newspaper=San Francisco Examiner|date=April 16, 1985}}</ref>
In July and September, 1985, the group adapted their nuclear weapon costumes for The Fashion Show presented by [[New Langton Arts]]. An original script read by the MC accompanied the runway show, titled "The Nuclear Fashion Arsenal", which was also performed a second time at Fort Mason for the [[International Day of Peace]].
In the group's third Tax Day performance, April 15, 1986, at Rincon Annex Post Office, The Nuclear Beauty Parlor enacted taxpayer robberies with pink machine guns.
In the 1990s, The Nuclear Beauty Parlor record was housed in the Audio Visual Collection of the Swarthmore College Peace Collection.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://fm12.swarthmore.edu/detail.php?dbName=AVCollection&rid=8650 | title = The Nuclear Beauty Parlor | website = fm12.swarthmore.edu | access-date = 2016-03-01 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://fm12.swarthmore.edu/detail.php?dbName=AVCollection&rid=5137 | title = Nuclear Beauty Parlor, The: ReStyles and the Final Rinse -- Awake | website = fm12.swarthmore.edu | access-date = 2016-03-01 }}</ref>
== Members and Names == The founding group members are Marissa Hutter LaMagna, Diana Wendling, Denise Slattery, Laura Graham, Lisa Andreini, Cecilia London, Kathy Staats Hornbeak, Marjorie Newman, Vicki Krohn Amorose and [[Fawn Yacker]]. Membership grew to include Connie Hendrix, Suzanne Stefanac, Kelly Cash, Lexine Alpert, Brenda Burson, Nancy Leszczynski, Siri Aarons, Christine Stiles and Suzy Poole.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
== See also == * [[Peace Action]] * [[Nuclear disarmament]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1320&dat=19861116&id=6NARAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5ekDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4346,12809 Hundreds of Marchers Hit Washington in Finale of Nationwide Peace March]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nuclear Beauty Parlor, The}} [[Category:Feminist art organizations]] [[Category:Political art]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:1983 establishments in California]] [[Category:1986 disestablishments in California]] [[Category:Politics of the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Artists from the San Francisco Bay Area]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
[[Image:RAFlogo.jpg|thumb|''Logo of The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship'']] '''The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship''' was founded by the [[Stuckism|Stuckist]] painter [[Odysseus Yakoumakis]] on September 2004, as the first, and currently the only, Greek group of [[Stuckism|Stuckism International]]. It has an international membership.
==History== [[Odysseus Yakoumakis]] discovered Stuckism in July, 2004, while surfing the net, and saw in it an antidote to what he deems "the ailments of the contemporary Greek 'artscape'".<ref>This issue is taken up in Yakoumis' article, "The Academic Provincialism of contemporary Greek Art and its proposed Stuckist remedy", to be presented by him at the first Stuckist international symposium [http://www.student.livjm.ac.uk/lsaiwyli/TheTriumphOfStuckism/index.html ''The Triumph of Stuckism''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060414172054/http://www.student.livjm.ac.uk/lsaiwyli/TheTriumphOfStuckism/index.html |date=2006-04-14 }} in Liverpool, England</ref> He contacted [[Charles Thomson (artist)|Charles Thomson]], the London founder of Stuckism, and a few days later founded The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship. He conceived this as a "Greek version of Stuckism, an antidote to contemporary Greek art's [[Parochialism|provincialism]], [[sectarianism]] and servile importation of [[post-modernism]]". He developed the concept of "Romantic Stuckism", that is of "Stuckism with a good injection of [[Eleatic]] and [[Platonic philosophy]], oriented rather towards encouraging each artist to pursue his/her genuinely personal artistic vision rather, than towards pointless polemics against the reactionary official art-establishment". He published the first two Romantic Stuckist theoretical texts on the Fellowship's website.
At that stage he was the Fellowship's only fellow and, as far as he knew, the only artist in Greece aware of the Stuckist movement. He contacted other fine artists in Athens, but described the reactions he got as "ranging from a tepid 'academic curiosity' to a sheer lack of interest or even, occasionally, to a politely concealed hostility." He was however contacted by artists from overseas and accepted them into the Fellowship. The first to apply was [http://www.ianjburkett.co.uk/ Ian J. Burkett], a painter living in London and founder of the Ealing Stuckists group. Shortly after, followed the painter and etcher [http://www.ilaniaabileah.com/ Ilania Abileah] from Canada, and the painter and etcher [http://www.artworksbyanthe.com/ Anthe] (who is of Greek descent) from the US.
==Under the Cover of Romantic Anonymity== Yakoumakis determined that Stuckism should, nevertheless, be brought "in the flesh" before the eyes of the Greek fine arts community, and organised the first Stuckist event in Greece, titled ''Under the Cover of Romantic Anonymity'', announced for May 14 of 2010 at the Ash-In-Art Gallery, Athens, Greece.
In parallel with the show, the new book by Odysseus Yakoumakis will be featured, titled "Leaflets from the Wilderness (a case study about the artscape in nouveau-Greece and many other lands)" (Ash-In-Art Publications).
Stuckist artists taking part include: *[http://www.ilaniaabileah.com/ Ilania Abileah] *[http://www.artworksbyanthe.com/ ANTHE] *[http://www.ianjburkett.co.uk/ Ian J. Burkett] *Odysseus Yakoumakis Guest artists participating are: *[http://www.song-rays.com/about.html Ray Wilkins] *Lefteris Yakoumakis *Vasilis Selimas *Nickos Delijannis
==Footnotes== <references />
==See also==
*[[Stuckism]] *[[Remodernism]] *[[Odysseus Yakoumakis]]
==References== *[http://www.odysseus-art.net/RAF/PostModernismCritique_EN.html Odysseus Yakoumakis, "A Romantic & Anonymous (nonetheless signed) Critique of Post Modernism"] *[http://www.odysseus-art.net/RAF/Manifesto_EN.html Odysseus Yakoumakis, "The Romantic Anonymous Manifesto"] *[http://www.odysseus-art.net/RAF/GreekAcademicProvincialism_EN.html Odysseus Yakoumakis, "The Academic Provincialism of contemporary Greek Art and its proposed Stuckist remedy"]
==External links== * [http://www.stuckism.com Stuckist web site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060424165552/http://www.stuckism-athens.org/ The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship official site] * [http://www.rosaspada.com/ Odysseus Yakoumakis official site] * [http://www.ianjburkett.co.uk/ Ian J. Burkett's official site] * [http://www.ilaniaabileah.com/ Ilania Abileah's official site] * [http://www.anthe.com/ ANTHE's official site]
{{Stuckism}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Romantic Anonymous Fellowship}} [[Category:Greek contemporary art]] [[Category:International artist groups and collectives]] [[Category:Art movements]] [[Category:Stuckism]]

{{Other people|Thomas Reed}} [[File:Thomas-german-reed.jpg|thumb|right|German Reed]]'''Thomas German Reed''' (27 June 1817 – 21 March 1888) was an English composer, musical director, actor, singer and theatrical manager of the [[Victorian era]]. He was best known for creating the [[German Reed Entertainment]]s, together with his actress wife, a genre of musical plays that made theatre-going respectable at a time when the stage was considered disreputable.
While acting as organist and chapel-master at chapels in London, and also as musical director and performer at [[West End theatre]]s in the 1830s and 1840s, Reed tried his hand at producing opera. He married [[Priscilla Horton]], a noted singer, actress and dancer, in 1844. By 1851, he was managing opera productions at various theatres in London and on tour. In 1855, Reed and his wife began to present and perform in "Mr. and Mrs. German Reed's Entertainments", consisting of brief, small-scale, family-friendly [[comic opera]]s. In the early and mid-Victorian era, the respectable middle classes regarded the theatre in general as sinful. Therefore, the Reeds shrewdly called their establishment the "Gallery of Illustration" and their productions "entertainments" to emphasize their refined propriety.
In addition to comic classics like ''[[The Beggar's Opera]]'', the Reeds usually presented new works by English writers such as [[F. C. Burnand]], [[W. S. Gilbert]], [[William Brough (writer)|William Brough]] and [[Gilbert Arthur à Beckett|Gilbert à Beckett]]. His composers included [[Frederic Clay]], [[Arthur Sullivan]], [[George Macfarren]] and [[Alfred Cellier]], as well as himself. Reed retired in 1871 after an injury, and his son Alfred took over the entertainments with his mother.
==Life and career== Reed was born in [[Bristol]], the son of Thomas Reed (1795–1871), a musician, and his wife, Frances, ''née'' German (1796–1839). He studied music with his father and made his debut at the age of ten as a pianist and singer at the [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] Theatre.<ref name=odnb>Stedman, Jane W. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/23278 "Reed, (Thomas) German (1817–1888)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online edition, Jan 2008, accessed 1 February 2013 {{ODNBsub}}</ref> The family moved to London where Thomas Reed was appointed conductor at the [[Haymarket Theatre]].<ref name=grove>Woodbridge Wilson, Frederic. [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/10942 "Reed, Thomas German"], Grove Music Online, Oxford University Press, accessed 31 January 2013 {{subscription}}</ref> The young Reed played, sang and acted at the theatre.<ref name=odnb/> In 1832, German Reed became an organist at the Roman Catholic Chapel in [[Sloane Street]] and assistant to his father, who moved to be conductor at the [[Garrick Theatre (Leman St)|Garrick Theatre]].<ref name=dnb>{{DNB Cite|wstitle=Reed, Thomas German}}</ref> His work at the theatre included scoring and adapting new operas, including ''[[Fra Diavolo]]'' in 1837.<ref name=dnb/> He also gave private music lessons.<ref name=dnb/>
[[File:A Sensation Novel.jpg|left|thumb|German Reed and [[W. S. Gilbert]]'s ''[[A Sensation Novel]]'', 1871]] In 1838, German Reed was appointed chapel-master at the Royal Bavarian Chapel and also became musical director at his father's former employer, the Haymarket Theatre, where he continued to work until 1851 with the exception of a temporary closure in 1843, during which he produced [[Giovanni Pacini|Pacini]]'s opera ''[[Saffo (opera)|Sappho]]'' at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]].<ref name=dnb/> During these years, he met Priscilla Horton, a successful and popular [[contralto]] and actress who had been performing on the stage in London since the age of ten.<ref name=grove/> They married in 1844.<ref name=dnb/> In 1851, Reed was engaged to assist in the production of opera at the [[Surrey Theatre]] and later managed Sadler's Wells Opera for a season and also conducted the music at the [[Olympic Theatre]], as well as touring extensively in the British provinces.<ref name=dnb/>
In the spring of 1855, at [[Queen's Theatre, Long Acre|St. Martin's Hall]], German Reed and his wife presented the first performance of "Miss P. Horton's Illustrative Gatherings," musical theatre.<ref name=odnb/> These performances usually consisted of one or two brief [[comic opera]]s designed for a minimal number of characters and performed with either the piano and [[Pump organ|harmonium]] or a small ensemble of musicians.<ref name=dnb/> They eventually became "Mr. and Mrs. German Reed's Entertainments", presented at the [[Royal Gallery of Illustration]] in [[Regent Street]], beginning in 1856, and later at [[St. George's Hall (London)|St. George's Hall]].<ref name=odnb/> At a time when the respectable middle classes regarded the theatre in general as sinful and even dangerous places of naughty humour, alcohol and prostitution, the Reeds called their establishment the "Gallery" of Illustration, rather than a "theatre", and their productions "entertainments" or "illustrative gatherings", rather than plays, [[extravaganza]]s, or [[Victorian burlesque|burlesques]]. ''[[The Times]]'' characterised the works as "extravaganza of the more refined order."<ref>"Obituary: Thomas German Reed", ''The Times'', 26 March 1888, p. 9</ref> Reed and his wife almost always appeared in these pieces, and on the few occasions when they did not, the box-office receipts suffered.<ref name=odnb/>
[[File:A-dream-of-venice.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Reed (in top hat) with his wife and [[John Orlando Parry|John Parry]] and Susan Galton in ''A Dream in Venice'' at the Royal Gallery of Illustration, April 1867.]] Reed became the lessee of St. George's Hall in 1867, and there he initially produced and conducted ''[[The Contrabandista]]'' by [[Arthur Sullivan]] and [[F. C. Burnand]], ''[[The Beggar's Opera]]'' and other English operas in small-scale productions, as well as non-musical plays.<ref name=dnb/> Around the same time, at the Gallery of Illustration, he presented works with libretti by, among others, [[W. S. Gilbert]], [[William Brough (writer)|William Brough]], [[Gilbert Arthur à Beckett|Gilbert à Beckett]], [[Robert Reece]] and [[Arthur Law (playwright)|Arthur Law]]. His composers included [[Frederic Clay]], [[George Macfarren]], [[Alfred Cellier]] and [[Hamilton Clarke]] as well as Sullivan and Reed himself.<ref name=odnb/> He wrote the scores for more than a dozen of the entertainments, and is described by the museum curator Fredric Woodbridge Wilson as "an imaginative and effective writer of music for the stage".<ref name=grove/> Little of Reed's music survives. A few individual songs were published, but the scores of the entertainments were not. The autograph of the music for ''Our Island Home'' is preserved in [[The Morgan Library & Museum]], New York, but no other scores are known to be extant.<ref name=grove/>
When the lease on the Gallery of Illustration ended in 1873, the German Reed entertainments moved to St. George's Hall.<ref name=dnb/> After falling from his horse when hunting, Reed had retired in 1871; his son Alfred (1847–1895) took over the entertainments with his mother, continuing with the entertainments after her retirement in 1879, until 1895.<ref name=odnb/>
German Reed died at St. Croix, Upper [[East Sheen]], [[Surrey]] at the age of 70. He was buried in [[Old Mortlake Burial Ground]].<ref name=odnb/>
==Works composed by German Reed== [[File:EyesandNo.jpg|right]] *''The Drama at Home, or An Evening with Puff'' (1844) *''A Match for the King'' (1844) *''The Golden Fleece, or Jason in Colchis and Medea in Corinth'' (1845) *''Who's the Composer?'' (1845) *''The Wonderful Water Cure'' (1846) *''[[No Cards]]'' (1869, libretto by W. S. Gilbert) *''[[Our Island Home]]'' (1870, libretto by W. S. S. Gilbert) *''Enchantment'' (libretto by Arthur Law) *''A Spanish Bond'' (1875) *''An Indian Puzzle'' (1876) *''The Wicked Duke'' (1876) *''Matched and Mated'' (1876) *''A Night's Surprise'' (1877) *''No. 204'' (1877, libretto by F. C. Burnand)

[[Image:vinegar tasters.jpg|thumb|right|A traditional representation of "The vinegar tasters"]] [[File:'The Three Vinegar Tasters' by Kano Isen'in, c. 1802-1816, Honolulu Museum of Art, 6156.1.JPG|thumb|right|Another representation of the theme.]] '''''The Vinegar Tasters''''' (三酸圖, three sours; 嘗醋翁, vinegar tasting old-men; 嘗醋圖, 尝醋图), is a traditional subject in Chinese religious painting. The [[allegory|allegorical]] composition depicts the three founders of China's major religious and philosophical traditions: [[Confucianism]], [[Buddhism]], and [[Taoism]]. The theme in the painting has been interpreted as favoring Taoism and critical of the others.
The three men are dipping their fingers in a vat of [[vinegar]] and tasting it; one man reacts with a sour expression, one reacts with a bitter expression, and one reacts with a sweet expression. The three men are [[Confucius]], [[Buddha]], and [[Laozi]], respectively. Each man's expression represents the predominant attitude of his philosophy: Confucianism saw life as sour, in need of [[Norm (philosophy)|rules]] to correct the degeneration of people; Buddhism saw life as bitter, dominated by pain and suffering; and Taoism saw life as fundamentally good in its natural state. Another interpretation of the [[painting]] is that, since the three men are gathered around one vat of vinegar, the "[[three teachings]]" are one.
The painting and its theme was featured in the book ''[[The Tao of Pooh]]'' by American Taoist writer [[Benjamin Hoff]].<ref>[http://www.taoism.net/sanctuary/books/vintaste.htm An excerpt from ''The Tao of Pooh'' by Benjamin Hoff]</ref>
==Interpretations==
===Confucianism=== Confucianism saw life as sour, in need of rules to correct the degeneration of people, and the present was out of step of the past and that the government had no understanding of the way of the universe—the right response was to worship the ancestors.<ref>(Smith 1996, p. 8)</ref>
Confucianism, being concerned with the outside world, viewed the vinegar as "polluted wine".
===Buddhism=== Buddhism, as it is practiced today, was heavily influenced and shaped by [[Siddhartha Gautama]], who claimed to be [[Enlightenment in Buddhism|enlightened]] when he was thirty-five years old. Siddhartha lived a very sheltered and extravagant life growing up. As he neared his thirties it is said that he became aware of all the ugliness in the world, this prompted him to leave his home in search of enlightenment. At the start of his travels Siddhartha became a beggar and studied [[philosophy]]; however, his studies did not lead him to the answers that he sought. He then tried [[asceticism]] alongside five [[monk]]s for six years; this practice also failed to bring him enlightenment. After giving up asceticism, Siddhartha decided to [[meditate]] until he found the enlightenment that he was searching for. After much meditation, he became enlightened and was henceforth known as Buddha, which means 'awakened one'. During his meditation he had a vision of humankind and the cycle that we are bound to. He concluded that we are bound to the cycles of life and death because of [[tanha]] ([[desire (emotion)|desire]], thirst, craving). During Buddha's first sermon he preached, "neither the extreme of indulgence nor the extremes of asceticism was acceptable as a way of life and that one should avoid extremes and seek to live in the middle way". "Thus the goal of basic Buddhist practice is not the achievement of a state of bliss in some [[heaven]] but the extinguishing of tanha. When tanha is extinguished, one is released from the cycle of life (birth, suffering, death, and rebirth)",<ref>(Hopfe/Woodward 2007, p. 176)</ref> only then will they achieve [[Nirvana]].
One interpretation is that Buddhism, being concerned with the self, viewed the vinegar as a polluter of the taster's body due to its extreme flavor. Another interpretation for the image is that Buddhism reports the facts as they are, that vinegar is vinegar and isn't naturally sweet on the tongue. Trying to make it sweet is ignoring what it is, pretending it is sweet is denying what it is, while the equally harmful opposite is being disturbed by the sourness.
===Taoism (Daoism)=== Taoism sees life as fundamentally good in its natural state.
{{Quote|From the Taoist point of view, sourness and bitterness come from the interfering and unappreciative mind. Life itself, when understood and utilized for what it is, is sweet. That is the message of "The Vinegar Tasters".|Benjamin Hoff|''The Tao of Pooh''}}
In the vinegar tasters picture, Laozi's (Lao Tzu) expression is sweet because of how the teachings of Taoism view the world. Every natural thing is intrinsically good as long as it remains true to its nature. This perspective allows Laozi to experience the taste of vinegar without judging it. "Ah this," he might be thinking, "this is vinegar!" From such a perspective, the taste doesn't need to be sweet, sour, bitter or bland. It is simply the taste of vinegar. By openly experiencing vinegar as vinegar, Laozi acknowledges and participates in the harmony of nature. As this is the very goal of Taoism, whatever the taste of vinegar, the experience is good.
At the core of Taoist doctrine is the concept of the Dao or "the way". According to Taoist philosophy, the universe originates from Tao, and Tao dominates the universe. "Tao is all embracing, existing anywhere and everywhere though it is invisible. It gives birth to the universe, which then gives birth to everything in it" (Sang, 87). The Tao in this sense is the way of the universe, the driving power behind all in nature (Smith, 198).
==See also== * [[Dharmic religions]] * [[Taoic religions]] * [[Three laughs at Tiger Brook]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * Hopfe, Lewis M; revised by Woodward, Mark R. "Religions of the World". Pearson Prentice Hall. 2007. p 176. {{ISBN|0-13-224045-9}} * Ji, Sang. Religions and Religious Life in China. China Intercontinental Press, 2004. * Smith, Huston. The World's Religions. New York: Harper Collins Publishers Inc., 1958.

revision.comment: added [[Category:Analog computers]]; changed 'External links' section to 'Further reading' since not all of the entries are external links
revision.text:
[[File:P.9 a volvella of the moon. A volvella is a moveable device for working out the position of the sun and moon in the zodiac.jpg|thumb|200px|A '''volvella''' of the moon. A volvella is a moveable device for working out the position of the sun and moon in the zodiac, 15th century]] [[File:Astronomicum Caesareum.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A sixteenth-century wheel chart, a page of ''Astronomicum Caesareum'' by [[Petrus Apianus]], 1540, apparently relating to the Moon. The red dragons mark out one odd-sized and 26 equal-sized central divisions; the [[orbital period]] of the moon is 27.3 days.]] [[File:Sacrobosco Lunar eclipse.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A volvelle from the sixteenth century edition of the ''[[De sphaera mundi]]'' by [[Johannes de Sacrobosco]].]]
A '''volvelle''' or '''wheel chart''' is a type of [[slide chart]], a [[paper]] construction with rotating parts. It is considered an early example of a paper [[analog computer]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Nick Kanas|title=VOLVELLES! Early Paper Astronomical Computers|journal=[[Mercury (magazine)|Mercury]]|issue=March–April 2005|url=http://www.astrosociety.org/pubs/mercury/34_02/computers.html|accessdate=2009-10-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710040825/http://www.astrosociety.org/pubs/mercury/34_02/computers.html|archive-date=2010-07-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Volvelles have been produced to accommodate organization and calculation in many diverse subjects. Early examples of volvelles are found in the pages of [[astronomy]] books. They can be traced back to "certain [[Medicine in medieval Islam|Arabic treatises on humoral medicine]]"<ref>{{Cite journal|title=On the Origin of Polyalphabetic Substitution|author=David Kahn|author-link=David Kahn (writer)|journal=[[Isis (journal)|Isis]]|volume=71|issue=1|date=March 1980|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|pages=122–127 [126]|jstor=230316|doi=10.1086/352410 }}</ref> and to the [[Astronomy in medieval Islam|Persian astronomer]], [[Abu Rayhan Biruni]] (c. 1000), who made important contributions to the development of the volvelle.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=State, Science and Economy in Traditional Societies: Some Problems in Weberian Sociology of Science|author=Bryan S. Turner|journal=British Journal of Sociology|volume=38|issue=1|date=March 1987|publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell (publisher)|Blackwell Publishing]]|pages=1–23 [12]|jstor=590576|doi=10.2307/590576 }}</ref>
In the twentieth century, the volvelle had many diverse uses. In ''Reinventing the Wheel'', author [[Jessica Helfand]] introduces twentieth-century volvelles with this:
{{quote|The twentieth century saw a robust growth in the design, manufacture, and production of a new generation of independent, free-standing volvelles. Categorically, they not only represent an unusually eclectic set of uses, but demonstrate, too, a remarkable range of stylistic, compositional, mechanical, informational, and kinetic conceits. There are volvelles that arrange their data peripherally, centrifugally, and radially; volvelles that use multiple concentric circles with pointers; and volvelles that benefit from the generous use of the die-cut, a particular technological hallmark of modern printing manufacture. Twentieth-century volvelles—often referred to as ''wheel charts''—offer everything from inventory control to color calibration, mileage metering to verb conjugation. They anticipate animal breeding cycles and calculate radiation exposure, measure chocolate consumption and quantify bridge tips, chart bird calls, convert metrics, and calculate taxes. There are fortune-telling wheels and semaphore-charting wheels; emergency first-aid wheels and electronic fix-it wheels; playful wheels that test phonetics and prophylactic wheels that prevent pregnancy.<ref>{{cite book|title=Reinventing the Wheel|author=[[Jessica Helfand]]|publisher=[[Princeton Architectural Press]]|date=2002|isbn=978-1-56898-596-1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lA26DBJI2YkC&dq=helfand+%22reinventing+the+wheel%22 }}</ref>}}
The rock band [[Led Zeppelin]] employed a volvelle in the sleeve design for the album ''[[Led Zeppelin III]]'' (1970).
Two games from the game company [[Infocom]] included volvelles inside their package as "[[feelie]]s": ''[[Sorcerer (video game)|Sorcerer]]'' (1983) and ''[[A Mind Forever Voyaging]]'' (1985). Both volvelles served to impede copying of the games, because they contained information needed to play the game.
==See also== *[[Slide chart]] *[[E6B]]

==Further reading== * [[Eye (magazine)|''Eye'']], [[List of Eye magazine issues|No. 41, Vol. 11]], edited by John L. Walters, Quantum Publishing, Autumn 2001. * Lindberg, Sten G. "Mobiles in Books: Volvelles, Inserts, Pyramids, Divinations, and Children's Games". The Private Library, 3rd series 2.2 (1979): 49. * {{cite web |title=New Volvelle Exhibit in NYC |date=2004 |url=http://robertsabuda.com/everythingpopup/nycvolvelle.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114211208/http://robertsabuda.com/everythingpopup/nycvolvelle.asp |website=robertsabuda.com |archivedate=2010-01-14}} An exhibition of volvelles at New York's Grolier Club.
